name: Meir Monumental Tombs
description: Meir functioned as a rock tomb cemetery for administration officials during the Old Kingdom-Middle Kingdom (6th-12th Dynasty), the necropolis of the governors of the 14th nome of Upper Egypt. The tombs are cut out of rocks with lower tombs on the hillside for commoners.

name: The Pyramids Of Meidum
description: Meidum, Maydum or Maidum is an archaeological site in Lower Egypt. It contains a large pyramid and several mudbrick mastabas. The pyramid was Egypt's first straight-sided one, but it partially collapsed in ancient times. The area is located around 72 kilometres (45 mi) south of modern Cairo.

name: Amarna
description: Amarna, located in the Minya Governorate of Egypt, is an archaeological site that was once the capital city of Pharaoh Akhenaten during the 18th Dynasty (around 1353–1336 BCE). It was originally called Akhenaten, meaning 'Horizon of the Aten,' as it was dedicated to the worship of the Aten, the sun disk, in Akhenaten's monotheistic religious revolution. The city was built rapidly on the east bank of the Nile, near modern-day Minya, and served as the political, cultural, and religious center of Akhenaten's reign. It included grand temples, palaces, and residential areas. The famous Amarna Letters, a collection of clay tablets with diplomatic correspondence between Egypt and neighboring kingdoms, were discovered here.

name: Tombs Of Beni Hassan
description: The Tombs Of Beni Hassan, located near the city of Minya in Middle Egypt, are a significant archaeological site dating back to the Middle Kingdom (11th–12th Dynasties, around 2000–1800 BCE). These rock-cut tombs were carved into limestone cliffs overlooking the Nile Valley and belonged to local governors (nomarchs) and officials who ruled the region of 'Oryx Nome.' There are about 39 tombs in total, but only a few are open to visitors and extensively decorated. The site is an incredible blend of history, art, and architecture, offering a glimpse into life in ancient Egypt beyond the grandeur of pharaohs.

name: Fraser Tombs
description: The Fraser Tombs are a necropolis located 10 km (6.2 mi) northeast of Al Minya, Upper Egypt. They sit around 2 km (1.2 mi) south of Tihna el-Gebel village, which was an ancient limestone quarry. The rock-cut sepulchres date to the Fourth and Fifth Dynasties of the Old Kingdom. These tombs were first discovered in 1853 by Heinrich Brugsch and described by George Willoughby Fraser. The tombs belong to a 3 km long necropolis of the ancient town of Mer-nefer(et). Four of the fifteen tombs contain statues and carved hieroglyphics dating from the Old Kingdom. The second tomb, likely of Ni-ankh-kay (Neka-Ankh), is the most important, featuring family statues in a mastaba-shaped offering room.

name: Tuna el-Gebel
description: Tuna el-Gebel was the necropolis of Khmun (Hermopolis Magna). It is the largest known Greco-Roman necropolis in Egypt, dating from the New Kingdom to the Roman Period, and saw heavy use in the Ptolemaic Period. Located in Al Minya Governorate in Middle Egypt, Tuna el-Gebel was mostly an animal cemetery during the Late Period. Burials included mummified ibises and baboons representing Thoth, as well as bird mummies, likely from nearby animal preserves and due to Thoth worship.

name: Zawyet Sultan
description: Zawyet el-Maiyitin (Zawyet Sultan or Zawyet el-Amwat) is a small village in the Minya Governorate, Egypt. South of the village lies a vast archaeological site with remains from the predynastic to early Islamic period. The site features a small pyramid from the early Old Kingdom, a symbol of royal authority in the provinces. It includes the Pyramid of Zawyet el-Maiyitin from the late 3rd Dynasty — the only pyramid on the east bank of the Nile — along with rock-cut tombs from the late Old Kingdom.

name: Abydos Temple
historical_significance: The Temple of Seti I is now known as the Great Temple of Abydos. In antiquity, the temple was known as 'Menmaatre Happy in Abydos.' Abydos is significant due to its connection to kingship, being the burial site of proto-kings from the Pre-Dynastic period, First Dynasty kings, and the location of the Cult of Osiris.
architecture: The Temple of Seti I features a standard layout from the Ramesside period with a 'L' shaped design made from limestone and sandstone possibly brought from Gebel Silsila. It includes the first and second courts with hypostyle halls, chapels to Seti I and various gods, and the Osireion. The South wing houses the Gallery of the Kings, which leads to a slaughter court and four secondary rooms, and continues into the Corridor of Bulls with a stairway leading into storage rooms, and the Hall of Barques.

name: El Hawawish
historical_significance: Al Hawawish Cemetery is considered one of the most prominent archaeological sites in Sohag. Located about 10 km east of Sohag and 7 km from Akhmim, it was Akhmim's main cemetery during the Old Kingdom. The cemetery contains over 800 tombs dating back to the Old Kingdom (2684-2160 BC) and the First Intermediate Period (2160-2034 BC). Nearly 60 tombs preserve inscriptions, scenes of funerals, offerings, daily life, dancing, hunting, and agriculture, with five particularly well-preserved tombs.

name: El Sheikh Hamad (Athribis)
historical_significance: Dating back to the 4th century BC, Athribis (El Sheikh Hamad) was founded relatively late compared to many other ancient Egyptian sites. The temple is located west of the settlement, with mud brick houses that have yet to be excavated. The Ptolemaic and Roman Period tombs of the city’s residents, dating up to the 4th century AD, are found in a nearby hill. Above the tombs are limestone quarries from which the temple’s stone blocks were sourced. The temple has a unique design with 26 columns, and its inner walls depict scenes of the daily procession of gods, each carrying a vase in the shape of a hawk’s head topped with a sun disk. The site also includes the rock temple of Ascalpius, which dates to the end of the Ptolemaic period.
architecture: The temple's design includes 26 columns, with walls of the Holy of Holies depicting scenes of daily processions of gods. The rock temple of Ascalpius consists of a court, a stone façade, and two halls carved into the rock. The temple's limestone quarries were the source of the stone blocks used for the construction.

name: Merit Amun Temple
historical_significance: The Temple of Merit Amun is located between residential buildings in Sohag Governorate, where modern Egypt is built on the same land as Ancient Egypt. The temple was built in honor of King Ramses II’s daughter, his favorite wife Nefertari. The statue of Merritt Amon, often referred to as 'the bride' by the people of Akhmim in Sohag, is considered one of the most beautiful statues, with her charm and Pharaonic beauty radiating around the city.

name: Shunet El Zebib
historical_significance: Shunet El Zebib, also known as Shuneh and Middle Fort, is a large mudbrick structure located at Abydos in Upper Egypt. Built around 2700 BC by King Khasekhemwy of the Second Dynasty, it was a funerary enclosure, a place to worship and memorialize the deceased king. It served as a precursor to later mortuary temples in the Old Kingdom period.

name: Catacombs of Kom El Shoqafa
historical_significance: The Catacombs of Kom El Shoqafa, meaning 'Mound of Shards', were named due to the mound of broken terra cotta objects such as jars and clay items, left behind by visitors who brought food and wine during their visit to the tombs. These objects were discarded as visitors did not wish to carry them back. During the discovery, heaps of these broken objects were found.

name: Citadel of Qaitbay
historical_significance: The Citadel of Qaitbay, also known as the Fort of Qaitbay, is a 15th-century defensive fortress built by Sultan Al-Ashraf Sayf al-Din Qa'it Bay between 1477 and 1479 AD. It is located on the eastern side of Pharos Island at the mouth of the Eastern Harbour in Alexandria, Egypt. The Citadel played an important role in the fortification system of Alexandria and was one of the most significant defensive strongholds along the Mediterranean Sea coast.

name: Roman Amphitheater
historical_significance: The Roman Amphitheatre was used for various artistic events, including musical concerts, until the 7th century. It served as an odeum for musical performances during the Roman period, and later became a conference hall during the Byzantine period for important meetings and public assemblies. The amphitheater was neglected during the early Islamic period until its rediscovery in the mid-20th century, making it a significant historical site in Alexandria.

name: Serapeum of Alexandria
description: The Serapeum of Alexandria was an ancient Greek temple built by Ptolemy III Euergetes (reigned 246–222 BC) and dedicated to Serapis, who was made the protector of Alexandria. It housed an offshoot collection of the Library of Alexandria. The Serapeum was the largest and most magnificent of all temples in the Greek quarter of Alexandria, located on a rocky plateau overlooking land and sea. Only Pompey's Pillar remains above ground today.
historical_significance: The Serapeum was referred to as the daughter of the Library of Alexandria, housing a collection of the library's texts. The temple also featured the worship of Serapis, a syncretic god. The site was destroyed during the late 4th century AD, but the Pillar marks the highest point of the area.

name: Abu Simbel Temples
description: Abu Simbel is an ancient temple complex, originally carved into a solid rock cliff, in southern Egypt, located at the second cataract of the Nile River. The two temples that comprise the site were created during the reign of Ramesses II (c. 1279 - c. 1213 BCE), with construction occurring either between 1264 - 1244 BCE or 1244-1224 BCE.
historical_significance: The Abu Simbel Temples are renowned for their colossal statues and their historical importance in preserving the legacy of Ramesses II. The temples were relocated in the 1960s to avoid submersion due to the construction of the Aswan High Dam. They are now considered one of Egypt's most iconic monuments.

name: Philae Temple
description: Built during the reign of Ptolemy II in 280 BCE (Egypt's Greco-Roman Period), the Temple of Isis at Philae is dedicated to Isis, Osiris, and Horus. The temple walls contain scenes from Egyptian mythology of Isis bringing Osiris back to life, giving birth to Horus, and mummifying Osiris after his death.
historical_significance: The Philae Temple is a major historical site in Egypt, featuring mythological scenes and inscriptions. It was relocated in the 1960s to avoid being submerged due to the construction of the Aswan High Dam. The temple's dedication to Isis made it an important religious center during the Greco-Roman period.

name: Temple Of Kom Ombo
description: The Temple of Kom Ombo is an unusual double temple in the town of Kom Ombo in Aswan Governorate, Upper Egypt. It was constructed during the Ptolemaic dynasty, 180–47 BC. Some additions to it were later made during the Roman period.
historical_significance: The Temple of Kom Ombo is unique in its design as a double temple, dedicated to two gods: Sobek, the crocodile god, and Horus the Elder. The temple’s unusual symmetry and the presence of medical and surgical instruments carved into its walls make it a remarkable site from both a historical and architectural perspective.

name: Temple Of Wadi El-Sebua
description: This temple was built by Ramesses II and was dedicated to the gods Amun and Ra-Horakhty, along with deified Pharaoh Ramesses II. Hence, it was then called the 'House of Amun,' and its construction was started in the 44th year of the reign of Ramesses II.
historical_significance: The Temple of Wadi El-Sebua is a significant example of the architectural and religious legacy of Ramesses II. It served both as a place of worship for Amun and Ra-Horakhty and as a monument to the pharaoh’s divinity. The temple’s location and design reflect the might and power of Ramesses II.

name: Bab Zuwaila
description: Bab Zuwayla, built in 1092, is one of three remaining gates in the City Walls, marking the southern limit of the Fatimid City of Cairo. It was constructed by the powerful Fatimid vizier Badr al-Jamali, who ruled Egypt from 1074 to 1094. It has twin minarets, which can be accessed via a steep climb. Bab Zuwayla was constructed, along with Bab al-Futuh and Bab al-Nasr, during the Fatimid period. Badr al-Jamali employed Armenians and Syrians in a vast building campaign, marking the beginning of a newly cultivated taste for stone in Cairo.
historical_significance: Bab Zuwayla is a key architectural feature of Cairo, reflecting the Fatimid period's strategic and cultural influence. The gate marks a significant part of the city’s history, both in terms of military defense and urban development.

name: Baron Empain Palace
description: In 1904, Baron Édouard Empain came to Egypt with the intention of expanding his commercial empire and building railway lines in Egypt. By 1906, the Baron hired the architect Ernest Jaspar to create a unique aesthetic in the suburbs of Heliopolis, which became known as the 'Heliopolis style'. This included Persian and neoclassical European elements. Heliopolis became a cultural center attracting people from all over the world, with infrastructure such as hospitals, restaurants, banks, and stores.
historical_significance: Baron Empain Palace is a key historical site, representing the blend of European and Persian influences in Egyptian architecture. It marks the creation of Heliopolis as a prominent urban and cultural hub in Egypt, designed to reflect an idealized modern city.

name: Salah Al-Din Citadel
description: Al-Muizz street runs from the city gate of Bab al-Futuh in the north to the gate of Bab Zuweila in the south, both entrances in the stone walls built by the vizier Badr al-Jamali in the 11th century. This makes it one of the longest streets in the walled city, approximately one kilometer long. Although the name al-Muizz street generally applies only to the street within the historic walled city, in practice, the road begun by al-Muizz street continues under various names further south, passing through the Qasaba of Radwan Bey (al-Khayamiya street), and finally ending at the great Qarafa necropolis (the Southern Cemetery or City of the Dead).

name: Mosque-Madrassa Sultan Hassan
description: The Mosque-Madrasa of Sultan Hasan is a monumental mosque and madrasa located in Salah al-Din Square in the historic district of Cairo, Egypt. It was built between 1356 and 1363 during the Bahri Mamluk period, commissioned by Sultan an-Nasir Hasan. The mosque was considered remarkable for its massive size and innovative architectural components, and is still considered one of the most impressive historic monuments in Cairo today.

name: Salah Al-Din Citadel
description: The Citadel was built on a promontory beneath the Muqattam Hills, a setting that made it difficult to attack. The efficacy of the Citadel's location is further demonstrated by the fact that it remained the heart of Egyptian government until the 19th century. During this long period, the layout and structure of the Citadel was repeatedly altered and adapted to suit the designs of new rulers and new regimes, which makes it difficult to reconstitute its original plan or even its plan in subsequent periods. There have been three major construction periods leading to the Citadel's current form: 12th-century Ayyubid (starting with Saladin), 14th-century Mamluk (under al-Nasir Muhammad), and in the 19th century under Muhammad Ali. The Citadel stopped being the seat of government when Egypt's ruler, Khedive Ismail, moved to his newly built Abdin Palace in the new downtown Cairo in 1874. Despite its elaborate defenses, the Citadel never ended up being subjected to a true siege, though it was implicated on various occasions in the political conflicts within Cairo or Egypt.

name: Dahshur
description: Dahshur was the southern part of the cemetery of Memphis, the capital of ancient Egypt. Pyramids of the kings of the Old and Middle Kingdoms were erected on this hill. The first king of the 4th Dynasty Sneferu chose the rocky plateau of Dahshur to establish his first pyramid to compete with the pyramid of King Djoser in Saqqara but failed to complete it. This first attempt turned into a broken shape, but he built a complete pyramid at a distance from it, called the Red Pyramid. Nearby, the pyramids dating to the Middle Kingdom, starting from the pyramid of King Amenemhat II, stand although in a bad state. The pyramid of King Senwosret III is surrounded by the tombs of the princesses Sit-Hathor and Ment.

name: Giza Plateau
description: The Giza pyramid complex, also called the Giza necropolis and also known as the Pyramids of Giza or Egypt, is the site on the Giza Plateau in Giza, that includes the Great Pyramid of Giza, the Pyramid of Khafre, and the Pyramid of Menkaure, along with their associated pyramid complexes and the Great Sphinx of Giza. All were built during the Fourth Dynasty of the Old Kingdom of Ancient Egypt, between 2600 and 2500 BC. The site also includes several cemeteries and the remains of a workers' village. The Giza pyramid complex consists of the Great Pyramid (also known as the Pyramid of Cheops or Khufu and constructed c. 2580 – c. 2560 BC), the somewhat smaller Pyramid of Khafre (or Chephren) a few hundred metres to the south-west, and the relatively modest-sized Pyramid of Menkaure (or Mykerinos) a few hundred metres farther south-west. The Great Sphinx lies on the east side of the complex.

name: Saqqara Complex
description: Located 40 km southwest of Cairo, Saqqara is one of the most important cemeteries of Memphis, which was itself one of the most important cities in ancient Egyptian history. The name of the site most likely derives from the god of this necropolis, Sokar. Saqqara is truly an open-air museum, one that has all of ancient Egyptian history on display. Kings and noblemen from the very first two dynasties (c.3040–2686 BC) were buried here, and this is also the location of the Step Pyramid of Djoser (c.2686–2667 BC).

name: Esna Temple / Temple of Khnum
description: The Temple is dedicated to the ram-headed God Khnum, the God of creation. Tuthmosis III laid the foundations of the Temple in the 18th Dynasty. Still, Ptolemaic and Roman Emperors completed it between 40 and 250 A.D. Their names are recorded all over the temple walls.

name: Hatshepsut Temple
description: Queen Hatshepsut gave the order to construct this magnificent temple in 1479 B.C. She built the temple to tell the story of her life, whose construction took about fifteen years to complete. The temple was designed by Hatshepsut's organizer; Senenmut.

name: Karnak Temple
description: Karnak Temple was built mostly during the Middle Kingdom to worship the sun god, Amun-Ra. The first monument at the Egyptian temple is believed to have been added during the Middle Kingdom by Wahankh Intef II. Sensusret I began construction during the Middle Kingdom. He built the temple of Amun.

name: Luxor Temple
description: The ancient Egyptians are known for their beautiful temples, and the Luxor Temple in Thebes is one of the most extraordinary. Dating back to 1392 BCE, the temple was built on the east bank of the Nile River and is dedicated to the deities Mut, Khonsu, and Amun. Its construction was begun by Pharaoh Amenhotep III and was completed by Pharaoh Tutankhamun.

name: Valley of the Kings
description: The Valley was used for primary burials from approximately 1539 BC to 1075 BC. It contains at least 63 tombs, beginning with Thutmose I (or possibly earlier, during the reign of Amenhotep I) and ending with Ramesses X or XI, although non-royal burials continued in usurped tombs.

name: Dandera Temple
description: The Dendera Temple Complex is an ancient Egyptian temple dedicated to the goddess Hathor. Located in Dendera, this Temple is a must-see for travellers interested in Egyptian history and architecture. With its well-preserved reliefs and stunning artwork, the Dendera Temple Complex offers a unique insight into ancient Egyptian culture. It dates back to the Old Kingdom of Egypt, around 3000 BCE. However, most of the structures and reliefs that can be seen today were built during the Ptolemaic Dynasty, between 305 BCE and 30 BCE.

name: Prince Youssef Palace
description: Prince Youssef Kamal Palace in Nag Hammadi was opened on Monday, September 30, 2019 after the completion of the restoration work. The palace was established in Nagaa Hammadi in 1908, and it was registered as an Islamic monument in 1988. The palace consists of 9 unique architectural units, built on an area of 10 acres. Youssef Kamal, one of the most prominent princes of the Muhammad Ali family, was a lover of art and traveled worldwide to buy rare paintings and gift them to museums. He is the founder of the Fine Arts School in 1905, the Society for Lovers of Fine Arts in 1924, and a co-founder of the Egyptian Academy of Arts in Rome.
